traceability.title: Traceability
traceability.description: ...as basis for building digital data chains and enabling data chain-focused use cases

sections.title: Introduction
sections.description: The aim of the use case traceability is to establish continuous data chains to track products, materials, automotive components and software along the value chain to empower use cases across the automotive supply chain. This is achieved via standardized registration of digital twins of components and vehicles as well as the logical linking of their parts lists (Bill of Material, BoM).

sections.title: Core Values of Catena-X represented in Traceability
How to contribute to Traceability and why?
Brief explanation of most important terms
Traceability subdivides the data models for each life cycle phase

subTitles: In this example, an “SME” produces components that have a part number (PRT-12345) and the batch (XX1235509). After manufacturing the parts, the SME creates a UUID for the produced batch via App A and automatically registers it in the Digital Twin Registry<0>Each traceable object is mapped via a digital twin and registered in the Digital Twin Registry as a digital twin. The Batch<0>Represents the master data of a batch after the assembly process. Relevant for manufacturers of components with large batches, which are produced under the same manufacturing conditions and bundled in a batch number. aspect model is used for this purpose. On the digital level, a contract is concluded via the SME and the customer's EDC<0>The Eclipse Dataspace Connector (EDC) is the standard connector within the Catena-X network that ensures secure and sovereign data exchange. connectors to exchange this data. The physical components (e.g. sensors) are then sent to the 'customer'.

The 'customer' is the manufacturer of an assembly. He creates a UUID for his manufactured serialized item (item number 5A52429 and serial number 21B294301268) via App B and registers it as a digital twin using the SerialPartTypization<0>Represents the master data of a component with its own serial number after the assembly process. Relevant for manufacturers of serialized individual parts or vehicle manufacturers. aspect model. The assembly relationship with the supplier's batch is established using the AssemblyPartRelation<0>Represents the relationship between the components after the assembly process. For example, which batch (gear wheel, raw material) is installed in which serialized part (transmission) in which vehicle. aspect model. He scans the components of the 'SME' and the identified data is linked to the digital twin of its serialized component. On the digital level, a contract is concluded via the EDC<0>The Eclipse Dataspace Connector (EDC) is the standard connector within the Catena-X network that ensures secure and sovereign data exchange. connectors of the 'customer' and the 'OEM' to exchange this data. The physical component (e.g. transmission) is then sent to the 'OEM'.

During the assembly process, the OEM scans the parts to link the vehicle (VIN/VAN = Vehicle Identification Number) to the serialized part. The OEM can then find the digital twin of the component with the information about the serial number and item number and thus read out the digital twin via the UUID. He then creates a UUID for his manufactured vehicle and registers it in the Digital Twin Registry<0>Each traceable object is mapped via a digital twin and registered in the Digital Twin Registry as a digital twin and establishes the assembly relationship with the installed part of the 'customer' using the AssemblyPartRelation<0>Represents the relationship between the components after the assembly process. For example, which batch (gear wheel, raw material) is installed in which serialized part (transmission) in which vehicle. aspect model.

sections.title: Opportunities to participate in Use Case Traceability
sections.description: Based on individual company needs, traceability offers various ways to participate in the use case. You can decide for yourself in which role (e.g. data provider and/or data consumer) and to what extent you participate in the use case. There are currently three options to connect your company and set up the required core components, such as the EDC.

detailsWithImageRow1.title: Self/Local Setup
detailsWithImageRow1.description: Individual and independent connection to traceability using the “do it yourself” guidelines.

detailsWithImageRow1.title: Minimal Setup
detailsWithImageRow1.description: Use of web services to set up the EDC and provide data via file upload for traceability as a minimal scenario.

detailsWithImageRow1.title: Complete Setup
detailsWithImageRow1.description: Use of business applications with full traceability functions...

sections.title: Business Applications inside Traceability
sections.description: The traceability use case is strengthened by a number of business apps which help the user to visualize and easy access the traceability chain. Below you can find an overview of all available apps. Use the direct link to open the app details page.

detailsWithImageRow1.title: Trace X
detailsWithImageRow1.description: Trace-X represents the open source application developed in the consortium. It enables seamless traceability of parts via the N-Tier supply chain.

detailsWithImageRow1.title: Smart MOM
detailsWithImageRow1.description: Is the solution via an edge device that consolidates all production processes and systems for controlling manufacturing processes.

detailsWithImageRow1.title: SAP Business Network . Material Traceability
detailsWithImageRow1.description: Enables cross-enterprise material traceability along the supply chain with seamless ERP integration and helps to identify and process affected products quickly and precisely with relevant business partners.

detailsWithImageRow1.title: Trusted Traceability
detailsWithImageRow1.description: links relevant data through a trust-layer across business partners and enables the required transparency.
